verses.text: A good name is better than precious perfume, and the day of death is better than the day of birth.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the surpassing value of virtue over outward riches. The idea that the day of death can be better relates to the hope of eternal life and the fulfillment that comes with a life well-lived under God.

verses.text: It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting, for this is the end of all mankind, and the living should take it to heart.
verses.comment: Reflecting on death encourages humility and repentance, reminding the living to consider their final end. The practice of meditating on death has deep roots in Christian spirituality.

verses.text: Sorrow is better than laughter, for by a sad face, the heart is made better.
verses.comment: Suffering and sorrow can have a purifying effect, leading to deeper wisdom. Compare with Christ’s teaching, 'Blessed are those who mourn,' which reveals the value of suffering when united with God’s will.

verses.text: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, but the heart of fools is in the house of pleasure.
verses.comment: True wisdom considers the seriousness of life and death, while foolishness pursues fleeting pleasure.

verses.text: It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise than to listen to the song of fools.
verses.comment: Humbling correction fosters growth in holiness; flattery leads astray. A reminder to value discipline within the faith community.

verses.text: For like the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of fools; this too is vanity.
verses.comment: Worldly laughter is fleeting and empty, producing noise but no lasting warmth or sustenance, reflecting the futility of a life apart from God.

verses.text: Surely oppression drives the wise into madness, and a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.comment: Even the wise are susceptible to injustice and corruption, a reminder of the importance of righteous conduct and keeping one’s heart pure.

verses.text: The end of a matter is better than its beginning, and patience is better than pride.
verses.comment: Endurance and humility are praised throughout Scripture. The process of sanctification leads to a glorious end, often hidden at the beginning.

verses.text: Do not be quick in your spirit to become angry, for anger lodges in the hearts of fools.
verses.comment: Patience is a chief virtue. Compare with Paul’s admonition against sinful anger, pointing to the need for transformation in Christ.

verses.text: Do not say, 'Why were the former days better than these?' For it is not wise to ask about this.
verses.comment: Longing for a nostalgic past can distract from God’s work in the present. God’s plan is always unfolding, even in challenging times.

verses.text: Wisdom, along with an inheritance, is good and profitable for those who see the sun.
verses.comment: Earthly blessings are best when accompanied by divine wisdom, highlighting the priority of spiritual gifts over material possessions.

verses.text: For wisdom is a defense as money is a defense, but the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom preserves the life of those who have it.
verses.comment: Both money and wisdom offer protection in life, but only wisdom saves the soul in the end. A subtle call toward the life of virtue and spiritual formation.

verses.text: Consider the work of God: who can make straight what he has made crooked?
verses.comment: This affirms God’s absolute sovereignty over creation and history, an invitation to trust his providence even amid difficulties.

verses.text: In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God has made the one as well as the other, so that man cannot discover what will come after him.
verses.comment: Trust in God during prosperity and adversity, recognizing his wisdom and providence in all circumstances. This calls to patient endurance, a recurring theme in Christian hope.

verses.text: In my fleeting days, I have seen everything: there is a righteous man who perishes in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man who prolongs his life in evil.
verses.comment: The mystery of suffering among the righteous finds fulfillment in the suffering of Christ, the ultimate righteous one who died yet triumphed over death.

verses.text: Do not be overly righteous, and do not make yourself excessively wise; why should you destroy yourself?
verses.comment: Self-righteousness and pride in one’s own wisdom can be spiritually dangerous. True righteousness is humble and God-dependent, found in Christ’s grace.

verses.text: Do not be overly wicked, neither be a fool. Why should you die before your time?
verses.comment: Warning against presumption and reckless behavior. The path of moderation and obedience is favored in the biblical witness.

verses.text: It is good that you grasp the one and do not let go of the other, for he who fears God shall come out from both of them.
verses.comment: The fear of God is the foundation of wisdom and the safe path between legalism and lawlessness. Compare with the balance advocated by Christ and the apostles.

verses.text: Wisdom strengthens the wise more than ten rulers who are in a city.
verses.comment: Divine wisdom is stronger than earthly authority, echoing the biblical theme that God’s ways transcend human systems.

verses.text: Surely there is not a righteous man on earth who continually does good and never sins.
verses.comment: All fall short of perfection, anticipating the New Testament teaching on human sinfulness and the need for a Redeemer.

verses.text: Do not take to heart all the things that people say, lest you hear your servant cursing you.
verses.comment: Human words are imperfect and can wound; the wise are slow to take offense. This encourages forgiveness and restraint.

verses.text: For your heart knows that many times you yourself have cursed others.
verses.comment: A call to humility and understanding, recognizing our own faults before judging others, echoing Christ’s teaching on mercy.

verses.text: All this I have tested by wisdom. I said, 'I will be wise,' but it was far from me.
verses.comment: True wisdom is elusive without God’s revelation. This sets up the need for divine grace and instruction, not mere human striving.

verses.text: Whatever exists is far off and very deep; who can find it out?
verses.comment: The mysteries of God’s creation and providence surpass human understanding, echoed in Paul's awe before God’s wisdom.

verses.text: I turned my heart to know, to search out, and to seek wisdom and the reason of things, and to know the wickedness of folly and the foolishness that is madness.
verses.comment: The earnest search for wisdom acknowledges both good and evil, a journey that ultimately points toward the need for divine guidance.

verses.text: And I find something more bitter than death: the woman whose heart is snares and nets, and whose hands are chains. He who pleases God will escape her, but the sinner will be taken by her.
verses.comment: A warning against seductive temptation and sin, consistent with broader biblical wisdom on resisting evil.

verses.text: 'Behold, this is what I found,' says the Preacher, 'adding one thing to another to find the sum.'
verses.comment: This verse introduces a concluding observation, reinforcing that true answers are not easily found apart from God’s insight.

verses.text: Which my soul has continually sought, but I have not found. One man among a thousand I have found, but a woman among all these I have not found.
verses.comment: Reflects on the rarity of virtue in humanity. The phrase should not be read as a condemnation of women, but as reflective of the Preacher’s experience and the overall scarcity of true righteousness (compare with Christ as the only true righteous one).

verses.text: Behold, this alone have I found: God made man upright, but they have sought out many schemes.
verses.comment: Humanity was created good but turned aside through sin, echoing the biblical narrative of the fall. This foreshadows the need for redemption found in Christ, and the necessity of grace to restore what was lost.
